an5.99:1.1: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his den,
an5.99:1.3: looks all around the four directions,
an5.99:1.4: and roars his lion’s roar three times.
an5.99:1.5: Then he sets out on the hunt.
an5.99:1.6: If he strikes an elephant, he does it carefully, not carelessly.
an5.99:1.10: or any smaller creatures—even a hare or a cat—he does it carefully, not carelessly.
an5.99:1.12: Thinking: ‘May I not lose my way.’
an5.99:2.1: ‘Lion’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
an5.99:2.2: When the Realized One teaches Dhamma to an assembly, this is his lion’s roar.
an5.99:2.3: When the Realized One teaches the monks …
an5.99:2.7: or ordinary people—even food-carriers and hunters—he teaches them carefully, not carelessly.
an5.99:2.9: Because the Realized One has respect and reverence for the teaching.”
